title-group.article-title: Exercise training improves neurovascular control and functional capacity in heart failure patients regardless of age

article-meta.aff: 1Heart Institute (InCor), University of Sao Paulo Medical School, Sao Paulo, Brazil.
2School of Arts, Sciences and Humanities, University of Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil.
3School of Physical Education and Sport, University of Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil.
4Departament of Medicine (Cardiology) and Physiology, Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA, University of California, Los Angeles, CA, USA.

author-notes.corresp: Carlos Eduardo Negrao, Heart Institute (InCor), Av. Dr. Eneas de Carvalho Aguiar, 44–Cerqueira Cesar–Sao Paulo–SP, CEP 05403-904- Brazil Email: cndnegrao@incor.usp.br

permissions.copyright-statement: © The European Society of Cardiology 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Background: Exercise training is a non-pharmacological strategy for treatment of heart failure. Exercise training improves functional capacity and quality of life in patients. Moreover, exercise training reduces muscle sympathetic nerve activity (MSNA) and peripheral vasoconstriction. However, most of these studies have been conducted in middle-aged patients. Thus, the effects of exercise training in older patients are much less understood. The present study was undertaken to investigate whether exercise training improves functional capacity, muscular sympathetic activation and muscular blood flow in older heart failure patients, as it does in middle-aged heart failure patients.

Design: Fifty-two consecutive outpatients with heart failure from the database of the Unit of Cardiovascular Rehabilitation and Physiology Exercise were divided by age (middle-aged, defined as 45–59 years, and older, defined as 60–75 years) and exercise status (trained and untrained).

Methods: MSNA was recorded directly from the peroneal nerve using the microneurography technique. Forearm Blood Flow (FBF) was measured by venous occlusion plethysmography. Functional capacity was evaluated by cardiopulmonary exercise test.

Results: Exercise training significantly and similarly increased FBF and peak VO2 in middle-aged and older heart failure patients. In addition, exercise training significantly and similarly reduced MSNA and forearm vascular resistance in these patients. No significant changes were found in untrained patients.
Conclusion: Exercise training improves neurovascular control and functional capacity in heart failure patients regardless of age.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Heart failure is a complex syndrome associated with exercise intolerance and poor prognosis.1,2 Both the incidence and prevalence of heart failure have increased in recent years.3 In addition, the incidence will increase even further due to the aging of the population and the increasing survival rates of patients with cardiac disease.3 Aging is associated with increased left ventricular mass, myocardial stiffness, atrial fibrillation and decreased maximum oxygen uptake.4 In addition, aging predisposes to diabetes, obesity and hypertension.5 All these alterations increase the susceptibility for developing of heart failure.3,4 Statistics show that the incidence of this syndrome increases progressively each subsequent decade and affects as many as 10–15% of people over the age of 65 years.3 In fact, heart failure has been a major cause of hospitalization in the elderly over the last 25 years.6

Chronic heart failure patients have abnormalities of skeletal muscle, including decreased mass and oxidative capacity. Several lines of evidence suggest that cardiac dysfunction increases sympathetic nerve activity and renin-angiotensin system activity, contributing to chronic vasoconstriction and muscle blood flow reduction that, in turn, leads to oxidative stress and inflammation.7,8 As the aging process is also accompanied by an increase in sympathetic activity and a reduction in vascular function,9,10 its association with cardiac dysfunction may have an additive effect on worsening of neurovascular control.

Exercise training is a non-pharmacological strategy for the treatment of heart failure patients. Exercise training has been shown to improve functional capacity and quality of life in these patients.11,12 Moreover, exercise training reduces sympathetic nerve activity and peripheral vasoconstriction.11,13–15 However, most of these studies have been conducted in middle-aged patients (<65 years). Thus, the effects of exercise training in older patients are much less understood.

The present study was undertaken to investigate whether the effects of exercise training on functional capacity, muscular sympathetic activation and muscular blood flow would be similar between middle-aged patients (45–59 years) and older patients (60–75 years) with chronic heart failure.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: Patients with clinical stable heart failure, aged between 45 and 75 years, New York Heart Association functional (NYHA) Class II to III and ejection fraction ≤40% were included in the study. Patients with unstable angina, recent myocardial infarction (less than 3 months), severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, uncontrolled systemic arterial hypertension and/or neurological or orthopedic disabilities were excluded.

sec.title: Study protocol
sec.p: Fifty-two consecutive outpatients with heart failure from data base of previous randomized studies11,13–15 of the Unit of Cardiovascular Rehabilitation and Exercise Physiology, Heart Institute, University of Sao Paulo Medical School. The patients were divided into two groups according to age: (1) middle-aged heart failure patients (45–59 years) and (2) older heart failure patients (60–75 years). Each group was further divided into an exercise-training group and a clinical follow-up group (middle-aged exercise-trained, n = 16; middle-aged untrained, n = 17; older exercise-trained, n = 11 and older untrained, n = 8). The study was approved by The Human Subject Protection Committee of the Heart Institute and Clinical Hospital, University of Sao Paulo Medical School.

sec.title: Exercise training programme
sec.p: The training programme was based on several published protocols that have demonstrated a conditioning effect.16–19 The four-month training programme consisted of three 60 min exercise sessions/week. Each exercise session consisted of 5 min stretching exercises, 25 min on the cycle ergometer in the first month and up to 40 min in the last three months, 10 min of strengthening exercises and 5 min of cool down. The exercise intensity was established by heart rate levels that corresponded to anaerobic thresholds up to 10% below the respiratory compensation point obtained in the cardiopulmonary exercise test. When a training effect was observed, as indicated by the patients using a Borg Perceived Exertion Scale, the bicycle work rate was increased by 0.25 kpm or 0.5 kpm to return to the target heart rate levels. Aerobic exercise training duration increased progressively so that all patients could perform 40 min of bicycle exercise at the established intensity. The control patients were instructed to avoid any regular exercise programme or any non-supervised exercise programme during the study.

sec.title: Forearm blood flow measurements
sec.p: Forearm blood flow (FBF) was measured by venous occlusion plethysmography as previously described.20 Forearm vascular resistance (FVR) was calculated by dividing mean arterial pressure by FBF.

sec.title: Muscle sympathetic nerve activity measurements
sec.p: Muscle sympathetic nerve activity (MSNA) was recorded directly from the peroneal nerve using the technique of microneurography, as previously described.21,22

sec.title: Functional capacity measurements
sec.p: Maximal exercise capacity was determined by means of a maximal progressive exercise test on a cycle ergometer (Medifit 400 L, Medical Fitness Equipment, Maarn, Netherlands), using a ramp protocol (5–10 W), as previously reported.13–15,23

sec.title: Blood pressure, heart rate measurements and ejection fraction
sec.p: Blood pressure was monitored non-invasively using oscillometric cuffs (Dixtal, DX 2710, Brazil, Manaus). Heart rate was monitored continuously through an electrocardiogram. Ejection fraction was determined from the two-dimensional echocardiography by Simpson's method.24

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The data are presented as mean ± SE or number of participants and (percentage) or (95% confidence interval). Possible baseline differences among the four groups were evaluated by one-way analysis of variance. The effect of exercise training in middle-aged heart failure patients and older heart failure patients was evaluated by unpaired T-test. The interaction of exercise training and age was analysed by two-way analysis of variance. Scheffé’s post hoc comparison was used to determine the differences between groups. In addition, the multivariable logistic regression was used to determine whether age was associated with exercise training changes. A p < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Baseline characteristics
sec.p:
Baseline characteristics are displayed in Table 1. There were no significant differences among groups in body mass index, left ventricular ejection fraction, peak oxygen uptake, heart rate, mean arterial pressure, MSNA, FBF and FVR. Table 1.

sec.title: Impact of exercise training
sec.p:
The effects of exercise training in middle-aged and older heart failure patients are shown in Table 2. Exercise training caused no changes in ejection fraction and peak VO2, heart rate in middle-aged and older patients. However, exercise training significantly reduced MSNA and FVR and significantly increased FBF in both groups. Table 2.
Effect of exercise training in middle-aged and older heart failure patients
Middle-aged untrained (n = 17) Middle-aged exercise trained (n = 16) Older untrained (n = 8) Older Exercise-Trained (n = 11)

Peak VO2 (ml/kg/min) 17 (15.6–19.3) 17 (14.2–20.7) 14 (12.3–16.6) 18 (15.4–21.1)

FBF (ml/min/100 ml tissue) 1.88 (1.60–2.15) 2.39 (1.96–2.81)a 1.54 (1.39–1.68) 2.18 (1.78–2.59)a

p < 0.05, b
p < 0.01 and c
p < 0.001. LVEF, left ventricular ejection fraction; VO2, oxygen uptake; MAP, mean arterial pressure; MSNA, muscle sympathetic nerve activity; FBF, forearm blood flow; FVR, forearm vascular resistance.

In relation to interaction of exercise training and age, we found that exercise training significantly and similarly reduced muscle sympathetic burst frequency (Figure 1A, exercise training effect, p < 0.0001 and age effect, p = 0.69) and muscle sympathetic burst incidence (Figure 1B, exercise training effect, p = 0.0001 and age effect, p = 0.87) in middle-aged and older patients. Exercise training significantly and similarly increased FBF (Figure 2A, exercise training effect, p < 0.0001 and age effect, p = 0.98) and significantly and similarly reduced FVR (Figure 2B, exercise training effect, p = 0.008 and age effect, p = 0.62) in middle-aged and older patients. Exercise training significantly increased peak VO2 (exercise training effect, p < 0.001 and age effect, p = 0.27) in both middle-aged heart failure patients and older heart failure patients (Table 3). No significant changes were found in untrained patients. Further analysis showed no significant association between age and changes in peak VO2 (r = 0.2039, p = 0.58), MSNA (r = 0.0579, p = 0.25), FBF (r = 0.1122, p = 0.93) and FVR (r = 0.0430, p = 0.27) provoked by exercise training. Exercise training improved NYHA Functional Class. After four months of follow up, 14 patients (82%) were in Class II and three patients (18%) in Class III in middle-aged group, and two patients (25%) were in Class II and six patients (75%) in Class III in older group. In contrast, after four months of exercise training, six patients (37.5%) were in Class I and 10 patients (62.5%) in Class II in the middle-aged group, and six patients (54%) were in Class I and 5 patients (46%) in Class II in older group. Figure 1.
Delta changes in muscle sympathetic nerve activity (MSNA) quantified as bursts/min (A) and bursts/100 heart beats (B) in untrained and exercised-trained middle-aged heart failure patients and untrained and exercised-trained older heart failure patients. Exercise training markedly and similarly reduced MSNA levels in middle-aged and older heart failure patients. MSNA levels were not significantly changed in untrained heart failure patients. Significant difference vs. untrained, ***p < 0.001. ET = exercise trained; UT = untrained. Figure 2.
Delta changes forearm blood flow (FBF) (A) and forearm vascular resistance (FVR) (B) in untrained and exercised-trained middle-aged heart failure patients and untrained and exercised-trained older heart failure patients. Exercise training markedly and similarly increased FBF levels in middle-aged and older heart failure patients. In addition, exercise training significantly and similarly reduced FVR in middle-aged and older heart failure patients. FBF and FVR were not significantly changed in untrained heart failure patients. Significant difference vs. untrained, ***p < 0.001. ET = exercise trained; UT = untrained. Table 3.

Values are for mean (95% confidence interval in parentheses). NS, not significant; LVEF, left ventricular ejection fraction; VO2, oxygen uptake; MAP, mean arterial pressure.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Previous studies have shown that exercise training significantly reduces MSNA and significantly increases muscle blood flow in patients with chronic heart failure.11,13–15 The present study confirms these findings and provides the knowledge that the reduction in MSNA and vasoconstriction after exercise training is similar in middle-aged and older heart failure patients. In addition, our study demonstrates that the benefits of exercise training in functional capacity, expressed by peak VO2, occur in both middle-aged and older patients.

Observational studies demonstrate that healthy older individuals have augmented sympathetic nerve activity when compared with healthy middle-aged individuals.9,10 Interestingly, our study shows that MSNA is no different in middle-aged and older heart failure patients, which suggests that a dominant influence on the increased MSNA in this syndrome is cardiac dysfunction. This finding is consistent with a previous study, in which increasing MSNA levels were associated with progressive left ventricular dysfunction.25

The mechanisms by which exercise training reduces sympathetic nerve activity in humans with heart failure remains poorly understood. However, findings in animal models provide information that the decrease in sympathetic outflow after exercise training can be, in part, due to the restoration in baroreflex control.26 Previous studies demonstrated that exercise training causes a significant increase in aortic depressor nerve sensitivity26 and a significant decrease in angiotensin II in the central nervous system that mediates the arterial baroreflex functioning.27 It is also possible that the reduction in sympathetic nerve activity is associated with an improvement in chemoreflex control due to an increase in nitric oxide synthesis in the carotid body.28

Aging gradually decreases muscle blood flow.29,30 This haemodynamic alteration has been attributed to increased intimal thickness, arterial stiffness, MSNA and decreased endothelial function.31–33 Our study clearly demonstrates that exercise training improves FBF in both middle-aged and older heart failure patients. This increase in forearm vascular conductance may be attributable to the dramatic reduction in MSNA. Additionally, exercise training has been shown to improve endothelial function and to increase blood flow in response to intra-arterial infusion of acetylcholine.34–36

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: We recognize limitations in our study. Aging is associated with increasing comorbidities and worsening heart failure. As we excluded patients with substantial comorbidities, there is no guarantee that exercise training will benefit all older heart failure patients. In fact, only one patient in the older group was unable to complete the exercise training programme, compared with four patients of the middle-aged group. Nonetheless, in those able to complete the training, we have demonstrated significant improvements in neurovascular function. Another concern could be that the differing distribution of the aetiologies amongst the groups could influence the results. However, this seems unlikely, since we have recently reported that the levels of MSNA and FBF are independent of aetiology in heart failure patients.37

sec.title: Perspectives
sec.p: Our study has several clinical implications. Firstly, exercise training is safe and feasible for older heart failure patients. Secondly, exercise training reduces sympathetic outflow and vasoconstriction in patients with heart failure regardless age. Thus, this non-pharmacological strategy should be recommended to older patients as well as middle-aged patients. Thirdly, MSNA and FBF are independent predictors of mortality in heart failure patients, thus the reduction in MSNA and the increase in FBF caused by exercise training may contribute to patient outcome independent of age. The significant increase in peak VO2 in exercise-trained patients reinforces this idea since this parameter is a marker of functional capacity and an independent predictor of prognosis in humans with or without cardiovascular disease.38

In conclusion, exercise training improves centrally mediated neurovascular control in heart failure patients regardless of age. Moreover, exercise training increases functional capacity in older heart failure patients to a similar degree as in middle-aged heart failure patients.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was supported by FAPESP and, in part, by Fundaçao Zerbini. CE Negrao, MUPB Rondon, LM Antunes-Correa and TS Nobre were supported by CNPQ. HR Middlekauff was supported by NIH RO1-HL084525.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
